name: Rui Do Rosario
comment info:
Headline: The States Are Covering the Spread...Sadly
1. I’m particularly noticing how spread out all of these states are right now compared to what they were in 2004. This indicates that states are starting to shift farther from a balance between republican and democrats, becoming strongholds by the year. The spread of states from a tie indicates how polarized our country is becoming, since each state is becoming strongly associated with one party or another. Therefore, our elections are constantly being decided by the few swing states. Only these states have a major influence due to the landslides every year in other states. I hope the parties won’t give up on trying to flip a state even if it seems out of reach. I also hope voters believe their vote makes a difference. Then all 50 states will contribute to electing future presidents. 
2. 
I wonder if parties will still spend time trying to win the voters of the states they had but now have lost. I think they should absolutely do so. Georgia was out of reach for Democrats in 2004 but has flipped blue in this most recent election. With this strategy both parties can win back states they previously had. 
3. 
Being from Boston, this will likely have a miniscule effect on my state. Massachusetts hasn’t flipped red since Regan and they have been shifting more left ever since. What I will say is that in General Presidential Elections, candidates will likely not campaign in Mass., for it is almost guaranteed Mass. will go blue.

name: Anna doRosario
comment info:
Title: Intricacies of American Politics Made Visual 

Context makes the graph all the more intriguing. Obama (in 2008) was able to increase the margin of victory in HI by a startling 35 points; so too was Mitt Romney (in 2012) able to increase the margin of victory in UT by a likewise startling 20 points. Obama is a HI native; Romney, the first Mormon to head a major party presidential ticket, hails from UT, the only Mormon-majority state. The prospect of "one of your own" in the White House caused Hawaiians and Utahans to turn out in record numbers. This begs the question: in the "United States" of America, why might your identity as a citizen of a state trump your identity as an American? Does love of state top love of country? In an age where voter turnout teeters around a measly 50%, Republicans and Democrats alike need to analyze the intricacy of factors that drive voter turnout up or down. Americans like to boast a rational electorate, but this may not be so. In an increasingly contentious political atmosphere, it's important to analyze how a voter's personal identity and sense of reason intersect to manifest as a vote for either candidate. The concept of identity is central to every human being and everything that human does; politics is no exception to this, for better or worse.

Maybe it's because people aren't satisfied with the state of the country and think the other party, that's not currently in office, can make life better for Americans.

This effects my community because I live in NJ, a primarily blue state. Although NJ hasn't voted Republican since 1988, I notice a lot of my classmates and a growing amount of people in my community are conservative. It will be interesting to see when/if New Jersey will vote Republican again and what factors will push them towards voting red.

US Elections: Shifting of Political Parties
